docs.snippet: Arthur Dunkel, a Swiss diplomat, shepherded negotiators from five continents through talks that led to freer trade and the creation of the World Trade Organization.
docs.lead_paragraph: Arthur Dunkel, a self-effacing Swiss diplomat who shepherded negotiators from five continents through more than seven years of contentious talks that led to freer trade and the creation of the World Trade Organization in 1995, died Wednesday in Geneva. He was 72. His death followed a long illness, according to a news release from the trade group's headquarters in Geneva.

headline.main: Arthur Dunkel, Trade Diplomat, Dies at 72

docs.snippet: Negotiations aimed at producing a new global trade pact are moving very slowly on trade in services, but a deal remains possible.
docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiations aimed at producing a new global trade pact are moving very slowly on trade in services, but a comprehensive deal remains possible next year, the director general of the World Trade Organization said here on Monday. Earlier rounds of global trade talks, including the Uruguay round that ended in 1994 and created the W.T.O. in 1995, focused mainly on trade in manufactured goods and agriculture, although the Uruguay round also covered some service industries like banking.

headline.main: W.T.O. Talks Moving Slowly, Chief Says

docs.snippet: Lillian Lux was the matriarch of a celebrated Yiddish theatrical family who performed for decades as an actress and singer in New York and around the world.
docs.lead_paragraph: Lillian Lux, the matriarch of a celebrated Yiddish theatrical family who performed for decades as an actress and singer in New York and around the world, died on Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 86 and lived in Manhattan. The cause was congestive heart failure, her son, Mike Burstyn, said.

headline.main: Lillian Lux, 86, Noted Actress And Singer of Yiddish Stage

docs.snippet: Vintage military aircraft enthusiasts spend years, even decades, painstakingly restoring World War II aircraft and other warplanes to airworthy condition.
docs.lead_paragraph: SURE, the old muscle cars stashed in Harland Avezzie's six-bay garage in Westfield, Mass., are pulse-quickening cool. But what really sets hearts soaring, among the lucky few who find this place, are the planes. Or, at least, their skeletons. Hanging from the rafters is a frame of a World War II trainer, a PT-19, that is said to have been flown by Charles Lindbergh. ''I haven't been able to confirm anything yet,'' says Mr. Avezzie, 51, who seems more excited about a husk of metal sitting on the floor: the crushed fuselage of a 1942 TBF-1 Avenger that was pulled from Lake Michigan 16 years ago -- one of five known TBF's left in the world. And if Mr. Avezzie finishes restoring the plane, it could be the only one flying.
docs.abstract: Rituals article on vintage airplane enthusiasts who collect and meticulously restore World War II aircraft and other war planes, all known as warbirds; Harold Avezzie of Westfield, Mass, Bill Fischer, executive director of Experimental Aircraft Assn's Warbirds of America chapter, Walter Ohlrich Jr, founder of Warbirds of America, Jim Jansa of Fort Walton Beach, Fla, and others tell stories about finding and restoring old planes; photos (L)

docs.snippet: For music listeners fascinated by questions of cultural identity, Jorge Drexler is the man.
docs.lead_paragraph: He was born in Uruguay, the son of a German Jew who sought refuge from Hitler in the New World. He also lived for a time in Israel, but when his own career as a musician began to take off a decade ago, he chose to return to the Old World, settling in Spain, marrying and having a child there and writing songs since recorded by Argentine, Brazilian and Cuban artists. For music listeners fascinated by questions of cultural identity, Jorge Drexler is the man. Virtually unknown in the United States until a song he wrote for the film ''The Motorcycle Diaries'' won an Academy Award in February, he has built a loyal following throughout Latin America with a different style of roots music: a highly literate body of work that often addresses complex themes like nationality, exile, language and history.
docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Latin American singer and songwriter Jorge Drexler, virtual unknown in US until Al Otro Lado del Rio, song he wrote for film The Motorcycle Diaries won Academy Award in February; Drexler, 40, was born in Uruguay, son of German Jew, lived for time in Israel and eventually settled in Spain; photo (M)

headline.main: Latin American Singer's Rainbow Coalition of Identities

docs.snippet: Luis Alberto Moreno, Colombia's ambassador to the United States, was elected president of the Inter-American Development Bank, decisively defeating João Sayad, a Brazilian economist. Mr. Moreno, whom the Bush administration favored to replace...
docs.lead_paragraph: Luis Alberto Moreno, Colombia's ambassador to the United States, was elected president of the Inter-American Development Bank, decisively defeating João Sayad, a Brazilian economist. Mr. Moreno, whom the Bush administration favored to replace Enrique V. Iglesias of Uruguay at the helm of an institution that disburses more than $5 billion a year in loans, triumphed in the first round, winning the support of 20 of the 28 countries eligible to vote, plus 56 percent of the bank's voting shares. Mr. Moreno will take office in October for a five-year term. Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: U.S.-Backed Candidate To Lead Development Bank

docs.snippet: Corruption in Latin American politics has emerged as one of the gravest threats to the democratic gains of the last 20 years.
docs.lead_paragraph: As he campaigned for the presidency in 2002, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva boldly pledged to clean up the sordid politics of Brazil. His, he vowed, would be an ethical, honest and moral government the likes of which Brazil had never seen. That pledge helped him win the votes of more than 50 million Brazilians and a sweeping mandate. But now, in a gloomy echo of what has happened time and again across Latin America, Mr. da Silva's government is mired in the biggest, most audacious corruption scandal in his country's history.

multimedia.caption: The Hidden Scourge: Wrestling With Corruption
multimedia.credit: Larry Rohter examines the impact of corruption on democracy and economic development in Latin America.

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: Larry Rohter examines the impact of corruption on democracy and economic development in Latin America.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline2: The Hidden Scourge: Wrestling With Corruption

headline.main: Unending Graft Is Threatening Latin America

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER and JUAN FORERO; Larry Rohter reported from Rio de Janeiro for this article, and Juan Forero from Lima, Peru. James C. McKinley Jr. contributed reporting from Mexico City

docs.snippet: Juan María Bordaberry and his foreign minister have been charged with "aggravated homicide" in the deaths of two congressional leaders in the 1970's.
docs.lead_paragraph: Juan María Bordaberry's years as president here in the mid-1970's are remembered as perhaps the bleakest in the history of this small country, marked by a wave of disappearances, torture and killings aimed at wiping out the remnants of the leftist Tupamaro guerrilla movement. But in March, a left-wing coalition government, including former Tupamaros, took power here for the first time. Now, in an end run around a 20-year amnesty, charges of ''aggravated homicide'' have been filed against the former president and his foreign minister for the most notorious crime of his era: the kidnapping and killing of two congressional leaders who had gone into exile in neighboring Argentina after the legislature here was shuttered and political parties were banned.

multimedia.caption: Uruguay Tackles Old Rights Cases, Charging Ex-President
multimedia.credit: Juan María Bordaberry's years as president in the mid-1970's were marked by a wave of disappearances, torture and killings.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Juan María Bordaberry's years as president in the mid-1970's were marked by a wave of disappearances, torture and killings.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: Uruguay Tackles Old Rights Cases, Charging Ex-President

headline.main: Uruguay Tackles Old Rights Cases, Charging Ex-President

docs.snippet: Energy runs like an underground stream beneath Osvaldo Golijov's "Ainadamar," a piece about Mariana Pineda and Federico García Lorca, as seen on Saturday.
docs.lead_paragraph: It is not every day that a character in a play invents the destiny of its author. But in the case of the revolutionary martyr Mariana Pineda and Federico García Lorca, who memorialized her in a historical drama a century later, a heroine seems to have arisen from the page, stepped down from the stage and said, ''You will die as I did.'' ''Ainadamar,'' Osvaldo Golijov's brief opera at the Santa Fe Opera Saturday evening, remembers the deaths of these two people but confesses its fascination with death in general. Pineda was garroted in 1831 by counterrevolutionaries not unlike the fascists who shot García Lorca in 1936. In the opera, their stories are told by way of Uruguay, where the playwright's erstwhile leading lady Margarita Xirgu is long exiled and approaching death in 1969.
docs.abstract: Bernard Holland reviews Santa Fe Opera production of Osvaldo Golijov opera Ainadamar; photo (M)

headline.main: Haunted by the Deaths of Martyrs, a Century Apart

docs.snippet: Alfredo Corvino was a dancer who became a distinguished ballet teacher during more than four decades at the Juilliard School.
docs.lead_paragraph: Alfredo Corvino, a dancer who became a distinguished ballet teacher during more than four decades at the Juilliard School and who accepted the invitation of Pina Bausch, one of his prize pupils, to tour as her company's balletmaster, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 89 and lived in Manhattan. His death was announced by Janet Kessin, a Juilliard spokeswoman.

headline.main: Alfredo Corvino, 89, Dancer And Juilliard Ballet Teacher
